Crowds should be prevented. Appropriate measures must be taken to ensure physical distance  between persons during the event, and to prevent direct close contact between persons.  This is achieved:  by reducing the number of participants, increasing the  capacity for passenger transport,  creating a planned schedule of arrival and departure of visitors,  by minimizing the possibility of grouping people at key points (toilets, places with  food).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211120191619/https://www.zzjzfbih.ba/preporuke-covid-19/

No change from previous policy    Larger events must adhere to capacity limits, and participants must have proof of COVID-19 vaccination, recovery from the virus, or a negative result from a COVID-19 test taken within the previous 48 hours.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211129233047/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/549896/bosnia-and-herzegovina-authorities-maintaining-covid-19-related-restrictions-nationwide-as-of-nov-26-update-34

Limit the number of guests to the smallest possible number, and in accordance with the currently valid orders of  the competent crisis headquarters - up to 50 people indoors. The presence of only celebrants and necessary  guests (eg high school graduates) and the necessary staff is recommended, with as few guests as possible (eg  family members). The presence of persons from abroad is not recommended, as well as persons older than 65  years.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211120191619/https://www.zzjzfbih.ba/preporuke-covid-19/
No change from previous policy - gatherings are recommended to be kept to no more than 50 people

Inform passengers about the importance of maintaining a physical distance of at least one meter from each  other.  The number and arrangement of passengers by seats must be such as to allow the prescribed distance  (1-2 m, or one empty seat) between them. Limit the capacity to the seats so that one person sits in a  row, in such a way that they sit alternately in the left and right seats. Mark unused places with a tape or  warning sign. We recommend that you do not allow standing and holding the handles while driving,  except when entering and exiting the vehicle.  All passengers must have protective masks, in accordance with previous orders.  An increased presence of auditors in vehicles is recommended. In public urban transport in particular, to ensure  compliance with the measures by passengers and the permitted number of passengers per vehicle.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211120191619/https://www.zzjzfbih.ba/preporuke-covid-19/

U.S. citizens wishing to enter BiH must have one of the following: a negative COVID-19 test (PCR or antigen) not older than 48 hours if coming from Europe and not older than 72 hours if arriving from other countries (including the United States); or a COVID-19 vaccination certificate showing full vaccination completed 10 days prior to arrival; or a doctorâs certificate of COVID-19 recovery in the period 10 to 180 days prior to arrival.  Children until the age of seven, accompanied by a parent who meets the above conditions may enter without a COVID-19 test or certificate.  Foreign nationals who are permanently or temporarily resident in BiH may enter without a COVID-19 test or certificate if returning from Croatia, Montenegro or Serbia with stays in those countries for less than 48 hours.  Citizens of Croatia, Montenegro or Serbia may enter without a COVID-19 test or certificate when coming directly from those countries.  The BiH Border Police website has detailed information on entry and exit requirements and exceptions. For the most up-to-date information, visit their website or contact them directly by calling their Operations Center at +387 33 755 300.    Requirements and restrictions may change without advance notice.  Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry? No.  See above.  Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? No  Nations bordering BiH also maintain border restrictions. For questions regarding those, please visit the following websites:    https://web.archive.org/web/20211120194232/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Foreign nationals can enter the country provided they possess documentation showing they have been fully vaccinated against, recovered from, or tested negative for COVID-19. The test must be taken within 48 hours before arrival if traveling from somewhere in Europe or 72 hours if arriving from outside Europe.    Cabin and freight crews, diplomats, foreign military personnel stationed in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and passengers transiting the country do not need to provide a negative test. Citizens of Croatia, Serbia, and Montenegro and their immediate families can enter without a negative COVID-19 test result, provided they are entering from their country of citizenship.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211129233047/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/549896/bosnia-and-herzegovina-authorities-maintaining-covid-19-related-restrictions-nationwide-as-of-nov-26-update-34    https://web.archive.org/web/20211129230641/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in BiH? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Private and public clinics throughout BiH perform PCR and serological COVID-19 tests. Payment is due in full at the time of the test and current prices are roughly 100 convertible marks (km) for PCR and 40km for antigen.  Turnaround of results and availability of testing appointments vary based on the city yet clinics in most large cities have testing options daily and return results within 24 hours.  A list of clinics known to provide COVID-19 testing in BiH can be found on our website here  Public Health Centers (Dom Zdravlja) test symptomatic individuals regardless of nationality, free of charge. To arrange a test, contact your cantonâs health center for additional guidance.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211120194232/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No policy change. "Foreign nationals without proof of a recognized vaccination seeking to travel to Switzerland from a SEM high-risk country for a stay here of up to three months without a visa and who do not meet any of the requirements under "Who is permitted to enter Switzerland?" are not permitted to enter Switzerland. These persons include:    -Persons who wish to obtain services in Switzerland;  -Tourists, visitors and participants in events;  -Persons who wish to come to Switzerland for medical treatment that has not yet begun or that is not regarded as urgently required;  -Persons seeking employment or who have been invited for a job interview in Switzerland;  -Persons who wish to submit an application for a residence permit.    A detailed list of the countries exempt from restrictions and an informative graphic can be found in the link below.    http://web.archive.org/web/20211116185435/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/empfehlungen-fuer-reisende/quarantaene-einreisende.html

Although the Swiss government was already restricting travel from certain high-risk destinations, it has further tightened travel limitations starting on November 26th. Specifically, it has intensified restrictions for travelers coming from South African countries amid concerns about the new variant. South Africa, Lesotho, Namibia, Botswana, and other countries where the new strain has been detected have been added to this list.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20211125023337/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/empfehlungen-fuer-reisende/quarantaene-einreisende.html

No evidence of policy change.

Tests are generally available in Switzerland. This is what can be read on governmental sources regarding the financial coverage of the tests:    "The federal government covers the costs of individual PCR tests in the following cases:    You are being tested because you have symptoms.  You have received a notification from the SwissCovid app.  You have been instructed by a cantonal authority or a doctor to perform a test.  The federal government does not cover the costs of PCR tests in the following cases:    You need a negative test result for travel purposes. In this case, we recommend that you inform yourself in advance how much the test will cost."    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20211113031533/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/testen.html

No policy change. The Swiss government continues using the SwissCovid app to trace new spikes. Schools have started full-time teaching, subject to compliance with hygiene measures. Facial protection are mandatory for everyone, social distancing is emphasized.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211125190607/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/education/high-schools

Workplaces are open but masks must be worn indoors and remote working is recommended  https://web.archive.org/web/20211125195733/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/face-masks-and-respirators/workplace

As of November 22, obligatory testing of employees starts again, once a week. Social distancing and masks are still in place within workplaces    https://web.archive.org/web/20211125200024/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/testing/testing-employees-students-and-pupils

Public and private events can take place with a limit of 1000 participants outdoors and indoors. If more than 20 people are present at the event, all those over 12 years of age must prove upon arrival their vaccination or recovery from covid.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211125201527/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/culture/social-events

Gatherings are allowed up to 20 people, with masks required indoors. If all the participants are fully vaccinated/recovered from covid, the number of persons allowed to gather is now limited to 1000 persons maximum.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211125201103/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/free-movement-people/measures-free-movement
Masks are mandatory in public transport  https://web.archive.org/web/20210827181006/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/hygiene/means-transport
No requirements.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211125201103/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/free-movement-people/measures-free-movement
Currently, no restrictions regarding free movement apply.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211125201103/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/free-movement-people/measures-free-movement

Travelers have to fill an Arrival form and get tested. Different requirements apply depending on the color-code categorizing countries. https://web.archive.org/web/20211115151350/https://covid.gov.cz/en/measures/travelling-abroad/arriving-countries-high-risk-covid-19-transmission

The employee could not perform work due to the quarantine order according to the relevant legal regulations.   The maximum amount of support: 80% of the paid salary (incl. Contributions), the maximum monthly amount of the contribution per employee is CZK 39,000.   The contribution will continue to be provided only to those employees whose employment lasts at least three months as of the date of submission of the monthly statement of paid wages  https://web.archive.org/web/20210827231544/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/compensation/antivirus-plus-forced-limitations-service-operation-and-quarantine
No change of policy found  https://web.archive.org/web/20211115152940/https://www.vlada.cz/en/media-centrum/aktualne/measures-adopted-by-the-czech-government-against-coronavirus-180545/
There is an updated government website   https://web.archive.org/web/20211122140145/https://covid.gov.cz/en/

Tests are available for all, they can be free of charge with a doctor request, paid for by the health insurance under certain conditions, or if none of the conditions apply, self-paid.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211125191554/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/testing/how-get-tested

Self-reporting is recommended and tracing centers are organizing the tracing effort. Children and parents who have symptoms of COVID-19 must follow the general advice to keep children home from school and get tested immediately.  Unvaccinated pupils over the age of 12 and primary and lower secondary school staff are strongly encouraged to take a test once per week.  Pupils between the age of 9 and 11 are strongly encouraged to take a test once per week. Children and parents who have symptoms of COVID-19 are encouraged to follow the general recommendation to keep children home from school and get tested immediately.    Pupils over the age of 9 and staff in primary and lower secondary school are strongly encouraged to be tested on a weekly basis, unless they are fully vaccinated or previously infected with COVID-19 within the last 12 months. Children and parents who have symptoms of COVID-19 are encouraged to follow the general recommendation to keep children home from school and get tested immediately.    Pupils from 1st grade onwards and staff in primary and lower secondary school are strongly encouraged to be tested on a weekly basis, unless they are fully vaccinated or previously infected with COVID-19 within the last 12 months.    Two weekly test are recommended in municipalities and parishes with high infection rates.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211127102306/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

From 26 November 2021 employees in the state and the regions are required to present coronapas. Physical attendance at the workplace is the rule unless otherwise agreed with the employer.  Corona passes are needed when attending a conference, unless the organizer ensures that there are 100 or fewer spectators / participants indoors and 1,000 or fewer spectators / participants outdoors. There are special recommendations for testing of staff in geriatric care as well as staff in primary schools who have not been vaccinated or previously infected (within the last 6 months).    At discos and nightclubs you must present corona passport/COVID Certificate or similar. Face masks are not required.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211202160355/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

Rules were updated on November 3    1) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents coming in EU/Schengen can enter Denmark. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected you must take a negative test before entering Denmark  or within 24 hours after arrival    2) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents from COVID-19 risk countries*, can enter Denmark without testing and without self isolating. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected you must take a negative test within 24 hours after arrival    3) People coming in from high risk countries have to get tested and also self isolate. However, those who are previously infected or fully vaccinated and have permanent residence or a residence permit in an EU-, Schengen- or OECD-country* or one of the COVID-19 risk countries/regions are exempted. Those with a valid certificate of vaccination are also exempted      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211104165021/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/categorization-of-countries

Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected you must take a negative test within 24 hours after arrival    2) People coming in from high risk countries have to get tested and also self isolate. However, those who are previously infected or fully vaccinated and have permanent residence or a residence permit in an EU-, Schengen- or OECD-country* or one of the COVID-19 risk countries/regions are exempted. 1) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents coming in EU/Schengen, OECD countries or  COVID-19 risk countries, can enter Denmark without testing and without self isolating. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected must take a test before/within 24 hours after arrival.    2) People coming in from high risk countries have to get tested and also self isolate. However, those who are previously infected or fully vaccinated and have permanent residence or a residence permit in an EU-, Schengen- or OECD-country* or one of the COVID-19 risk countries/regions are exempted. Those with a valid certificate of vaccination are also exempted    3)  People coming in from areas with COVID-19 variants of concern within 10 days prior to the date of entering Denmark, must take a test within 24 hours of entry and immediately self-isolate for 10 days. The isolation may be ended with a negative PCR-test taken at least four days after arrival. Those who  have stayed in a country, region or area with COVID-19 variants of concern between 5 and 10 days before entry to Denmark, can interrupt the isolation by a negative PCR test, which is performed immediately after entry, and otherwise with a negative PCR test, which is performed at the earliest on the fourth day after entry    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211127110428/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/categorization-of-countries

1) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents coming in EU/Schengen, OECD countries or  COVID-19 risk countries, can enter Denmark without testing and without self isolating. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected must take a test before/within 24 hours after arrival.    3)  People coming in from areas with COVID-19 variants of concern within 10 days prior to the date of entering Denmark, must take a test within 24 hours of entry and immediately self-isolate for 10 days. The isolation may be ended with a negative PCR-test taken at least six days after arrival.     Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211202161750/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/covidtravelrules

In Denmark, a face mask or shield is required at the airport. People are also advised to wear a face mask or shield at test centres or when visiting the hospital. However, some groups are exempt from the required use of face mask or shield. These include, for instance, children up to the age of 12, people with a decreased level of consciousness, or people with physical or mental impairments that make it impossible for them to remove the face mask or shield themselves. Face masks may be removed if the wearer experience a severe discomfort, such as difficulty breathing.    Archived: Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211104164422/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations?__cf_chl_captcha_tk__=f09POh16Rm6v8Z2737eWSCzgNIsL3bD6OmZdjoeyKaU-1636044217-0-gaNycGzNC-U

It is also required to wear a face mask or shield in grocery stores, shops and in shopping centres. There is a coordinated public campaign with information on the government website    https://web.archive.org/web/20211126180943/https://kriis.ee/en

In most cases, family physicians or the Health Board must refer their patients to testing. Specific providers can also provide tests for a fee to anyone who wants to be tested.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211112160814/https://www.terviseamet.ee/en/testing-virus
Contract tracing is done through the HOIA mobile app    https://web.archive.org/web/20211123142130/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/coronavirus-and-preventing-its-spread/hoia-mobile-app

A protective mask is obligatory in public indoor spaces (including rooms where COVID certificate is checked, e.g. cinema, theatre, events, trainings etc).     https://web.archive.org/web/20211126181926/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/coronavirus-and-preventing-its-spread/personal-protection-equipment---masks-and-similar

All Estonian people (over the age of twelve) can get vaccinated against COVID-19 for free.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211116185452/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/covid-19-vaccination/vaccination-plan-and-risk-groups

Recommendations of sanitary measures are made for visitors of care homes. There is also a policy that the care homes have to follow in case of suspicion of infection.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211112163407/https://www.kriis.ee/en/everyday-life-and-services/medical-aid-pharmacies-and-social-care/social-care

In the area of ??the Hospital Districts of Southern Ostrobothnia and Central Ostrobothnia, an indoor event of up to of 100 people may be held, if:    1) there are auditoriums where no seating is provided for all participants,  or   2) there are joint singing events belonging to public events.   Other types of public events and general meetings are allowed. The organizer of the events described above may introduce a corona passport as an alternative to the existing corona restrictions, in which case the passport will allow admission to events and activities.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211115172413/https://avi.fi/usein-kysyttya-koronaviruksesta

In Southwest Finland, indoor events is restricted to 50 people however, the event organizer may introduce a corona passport as an alternative to the restrictions, in which case the passport will allow admission to events and activities. Other types of public events and general meetings are allowed.     In the area of the Hospital Districts of Southern Ostrobothnia and Central Ostrobothnia, an indoor event of up to of 100 people may be held, if:    1) there are auditoriums where no seating is provided for all participants,  or   2) there are joint singing events belonging to public events. Other types of public events and general meetings are allowed. The organizer of the events described above may introduce a corona passport as an alternative to the existing corona restrictions, in which case the passport will allow admission to events and activities.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211118023621/https://avi.fi/usein-kysyttya-koronaviruksesta

Vaccinated travelers from all countries are now permitted to enter Finland. However, this requires having received the last dose of a valid COVID-19 vaccine at least 14 days prior to arrival. People coming in from countries marked as risk countries who do no not have a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test, proof of having had the disease or a vaccination certificate, would have to be tested for COVID-19 on entry into the country. This test is mandatory.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211104162011/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic

Vaccinated travelers from all countries are now permitted to enter Finland. However, this requires having received the last dose of a valid COVID-19 vaccine at least 14 days prior to arrival. People coming in from countries marked as risk countries who do no not have a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test, proof of having had the disease or a vaccination certificate, would have to be tested for COVID-19 on entry into the country. This test is mandatory    The Finnish Institute of Health and Welfare recommends avoiding all travel to South Africa, Namibia, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Lesotho, Eswatini (Swaziland), Malawi and Mozambique based on the new COVID-19 variant (B.1.1.529)    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211127120233/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic

Vaccinated travelers from all countries are now permitted to enter Finland. However, this requires having received the last dose of a valid COVID-19 vaccine at least 14 days prior to arrival. People coming in from countries marked as risk countries who do no not have a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test, proof of having had the disease or a vaccination certificate, would have to be tested for COVID-19 on entry into the country. This test is mandatory    The Finnish Institute of Health and Welfare has restricted all travel to South Africa, Namibia, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Lesotho, Eswatini (Swaziland), Malawi and Mozambique based on the new COVID-19 variant (B.1.1.529) from 27th November. This regulation does not apply to children under 6 years if age    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211202165702/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic

The amendment to the unemployment benefit legislation will be extended until 30 November 2021. Those laid off temporarily and the lay-off started on or after 16 March 2020, are eligible for an unemployment benefit even if they are studying. This is a temporary change that will be effective until 31 December 2021.      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211017165013/https://www.kela.fi/web/en/unemployment-benefit-corona  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017164755/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Testing is recommended not only for those who are symptomatic, but also for those among these group who have been exposed to the virus:  those who are unvaccinated, those have received only one vaccine dose of a series of two doses, those are fully vaccinated but less than a week has elapsed since the second dose of the vaccine and have been exposed to coronavirus within the last two weeks, and those who belong to a group for which a third dose of vaccine is recommended, but you have not yet received a third dose.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211202170009/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/symptoms-and-treatment-coronavirus/coronavirus-tests

A mobile app "Koronavilkku",  is a contact tracing app was produced by the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) to help people find out whether you may have been exposed to coronavirus. The app can also be used to send share positive tests results anonymously with those you have been in close contact with. From 15 November, all Departments move to Level 2/Yellow health protocol irrespective of the incidence rate of Covid-19 in the local population, with facial coverings required for all Elementary school pupils. Previously, level 1 / green level restrictions were applied in Departments whose incidence rate was below a threshold of 50 per 100,000 inhabitants over a period of 5 consecutive days.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211115032112/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20211115032052/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

All schools in France remain at the Level 2/Yellow level introduced on 15 November, irrespective of the incidence rate of Covid-19 in the local population. Facial coverings are required for all Elementary school pupils, and also for University students. Schools and Universities remain open, with barrier measures in place. https://web.archive.org/web/20211119230206/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education    From 29 November, rules concerning the closure of classes for a period of 7 days from detection of the first positive case will no longer apply to Elementary schools: students with a negative test within 24 hours will be able to continue to go to class. Middle school students from the 6th year on or after the age of 6 who have a complete vaccination schedule can continue face-to-face classes. Unvaccinated students must attend classes from home during the isolation period. https://web.archive.org/web/20211128075403/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

No change in policy, or to the list of the Red/Orange/Green countries recorded on 6 November. https://web.archive.org/web/20211115045031/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

No change in policy, entry to France remains controlled depending on the vaccination status, reason for traveling, and country of traveler origin. Origin countries are categorised as Green/Orange/Red depending on Covid-19 prevalence.     Ukraine was added to the list of Red category countries on 13 November. The list is now as follows:     - "Green" countries/territories: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, Canada, Chile, comoros, Hong Kong, Japan, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, South Korea, Taiwan, the United Arab Emirates, Uruguay and Vanuatu.    - "Orange" countries/territories: countries/territories in which there is active circulation of the virus in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories.    - "Red" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed with the presence of variants of concern. These are: Afghanistan, Brazil, Costa Rica, Cuba, Georgia, Moldova, Montenegro, Pakistan, Russia, Serbia, Suriname, Turkey and Ukraine.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211119231143/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

The list is now as follows:     - "Green" countries/territories: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, Canada, Chile, comoros, Hong Kong, Japan, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, South Korea, Taiwan, the United Arab Emirates, Uruguay and Vanuatu.    - "Orange" countries/territories: countries/territories in which there is active circulation of the virus in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories.    - "Red" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed with the presence of variants of concern. These are: Afghanistan, Belarus, Brazil, Costa Rica, Cuba, Georgia, Moldova, Montenegro, Pakistan, Russia, Serbia, Suriname, Turkey and Ukraine.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211123221056/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19#nav-main-menu

Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, and Zimbabwe were added to the list of Red category countries on 27 November. The list is now as follows:     - "Green" countries/territories: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, Canada, Chile, comoros, Hong Kong, Japan, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, South Korea, Taiwan, the United Arab Emirates, Uruguay and Vanuatu.    - "Orange" countries/territories: countries/territories in which there is active circulation of the virus in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories.    - "Red" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed with the presence of variants of concern. These are: Afghanistan, Belarus, Botswana, Brazil, Costa Rica, Cuba, Eswatini, Georgia, Lesotho, Moldova, Montenegro, Mozambique, Namibia, Pakistan, Russia, Serbia, South Africa, Suriname, Turkey, Ukraine and Zimbabwe.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211128075535/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19#main

No change in policy, vaccination is universally available to people aged over 12 years and 2 months. On  9 November, President Macron "called on the French who are not yet vaccinated to do so and made several announcements relating to the health situation:    as of 15 December, people over the age of 65 and people who have been vaccinated with the Janssen vaccine must have completed their booster to keep their health pass valid;  the recall campaign will be extended at the beginning of December to French people aged 50 to 64;"    https://web.archive.org/web/20211115045128/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

No change in policy, vaccination is universally available to people aged over 12 years and 2 months. The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211115175717/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

No change in policy, vaccination is universally available to people aged over 12 years and 2 months. Vaccination is universally available to people aged over 12 years and 2 months. The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     From November 27, vaccination boosters are avaialble to all people 18 years of age and older from five months after the last injection or infection with Covid-19. From     From December 15, rules for the Health Pass are changing for people aged 65 and over, and people vaccinated with Janssen. From this date, these people must have received a booster vaccine, from the moment they are eligible (i.e. 6 months after their last injection for the first and 1 month for the second), and at the end of a period of 4 additional weeks maximum. Beyond this time, their QR code will be deactivated automatically.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211128075648/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

No change in policy: in addition to the protections afforded to the general population, vaccination is mandatory for all people in contact with frail and elderly people, including caregivers, non-caregivers, professionals and volunteers. https://web.archive.org/web/20211115045128/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

In addition to the protections afforded to the general population, vaccination is mandatory for all people in contact with frail and elderly people, including caregivers, non-caregivers, professionals and volunteers.     On 9 November, President Macron announced that it would be mandatory for people aged 65 and over who have been vaccinated with the Janssen (Johnson & Johnson) vaccine

In addition to the protections afforded to the general population, vaccination is mandatory for all people in contact with frail and elderly people, including caregivers, non-caregivers, professionals and volunteers.     From December 15, rules for the Health Pass are changing for people aged 65 and over, and people vaccinated with Janssen. From this date, these people must have received a booster vaccine, from the moment they are eligible (i.e. 6 months after their last injection for the first and 1 month for the second), and at the end of a period of 4 additional weeks maximum. Beyond this time, their QR code will be deactivated automatically.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211128075648/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Updated 3. November 2021  All travellers should be tested two days after arrival to the Faroe Islands.    Mandatory testing upon arrival to the Faroe Islands:  In addition to the recommendations above, the Epidemic Commission will require corona tests from all travellers who are unable to present a valid COVID Certificate. That is persons, who have not been fully vaccinated, and cannot present a valid corona test (not older than 72 hours) or have not been previously infected by corona (antibody test) must all be tested upon arrival in the Faroe Islands. This will apply from 15th of November 2021.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211129054842/https://korona.fo/current-recommendations?_l=en

Testing in the Faroe Islands:  Testing is free of charge, but you must pre-register.  Once you have registered, you will receive a notification by phone and email, which you are asked to show on arrival.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211123172309/https://korona.fo/testing?_l=en

If you have symptoms:  If you are experiencing any of the symptoms mentioned above - whether these are common or uncommon - and/or have been in close contact with someone who has been infected by COVID19, you should first call your local doctor on weekdays between 08:00 and 16:00. If you do not have an assigned GP in your municipality, you should contact any local GP in your area.    After 16:00 on weekdays and during weekends you should call the after-hours GP service on 1870.    To avoid possible further infection, do not go to your doctor in person.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211123172302/https://korona.fo/symptoms?_l=en

Friday 26 November 2021    Travellers arriving in England from several southern African countries will have to quarantine amid warnings over a new coronavirus variant.    UK Health Secretary Sajid Javid said from 12:00 GMT on Friday six countries would be added to the red list, with flights being temporarily banned.    One expert described the variant, known as B.1.1.529, as "the worst one we've seen so far", and there is concern it has the potential to evade immunity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211126015008/https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-59424269

As of October 4, in-person studies have resumed in classrooms and auditoria, and in preschool facilities, with facemask use mandatory for all students.  http://web.archive.org/web/20211128162627/https://stopcov.ge/en/page/restrictions-list

Public institutions are instructed to move their staff onto the remote format of work to the maximum extent possible and similar recommendation is given by the Council to employers in the private sector.  http://web.archive.org/web/20211128162627/https://stopcov.ge/en/page/restrictions-list

Any type of entertainment activities, arts and culture events (except for stage performances and cinema), festivals are going to be fully banned. The referred restriction does not apply to concerts to be held at the premises of hotels. As for sports tournaments of various types, they may be held without spectators. Nevertheless, every participant should be vaccinated (14 days should be lapsed from the second dose) or have a PCR test result obtained in the past 72 hours or a negative result of an antigen test obtained in the past 24 hours.  http://web.archive.org/web/20211128162627/https://stopcov.ge/en/page/restrictions-list

Restriction remains valid on holding the wide-scale entertainment and such social events, as wedding parties, banquets, jubilees of various types and similar. Eateries and ritual venues of miscellaneous types will be sanctioned with 10 000 GEL for hosting such events but will be sealed if found in breach of the regulation for the second time.  There is no limit on number mentioned on the government website so it is assumed the restriction has not changed.  http://web.archive.org/web/20211128162627/https://stopcov.ge/en/page/restrictions-list

Public transport is operating. Face masks must be worn in all enclosed public spaces, including taxis and public transportation.  http://web.archive.org/web/20211128165656/https://ge.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-on-georgia/
Starting June 30, 11 PM curfew will be lifted.  http://web.archive.org/web/20211128162627/https://stopcov.ge/en/page/restrictions-list
No restrictions on intercity or interstate travel. http://web.archive.org/web/20211128165656/https://ge.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-on-georgia/

Land borders of Georgia are open from June 1, 2021 in line with a decision made by the Inter-Agency Coordination Council. Border crossing is currently permitted to citizens of EU member states and 40 countries  in addition, as well as to individuals with a permission of residence. They need to present the following at the border crossing: document evidencing a full cycle of vaccination and a negative result of PCR test obtained in the past 72 hours, or alternatively present only a negative PCR test result obtained 72 hours prior to the visit to Georgia and get a repeated PCR test on the 3rd day of their stay in Georgia at their own expense.  When crossing the border of Georgia with a negative PCR test, it is mandatory to fill in the electronic application, uploaded to stopcov.ge.  When entering the country, foreign nationals who have had COVID-19 and are vaccinated with one dose, will be subject to the same regulation as applicable to individuals vaccinated with both doses.  http://web.archive.org/web/20211128162627/https://stopcov.ge/en/page/restrictions-list

As of 28 November 2021, Georgian and foreign citizens travelling from eight countries, including South Africa, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Namibia, Lesotho, Eswatini (Swaziland), Mozambique and Malawi, will need to quarantine for 14 days following the emergence of Covid-19 variant in South Africa.  http://web.archive.org/web/20211128195455/https://agenda.ge/en/news/2021/3750

No current debt/contract relief measures found.   http://web.archive.org/web/20211128173625/https://stopcov.ge/en/Gegma
No change, website providing information on recommendations and restrictions.  http://web.archive.org/web/20211128174752/https://stopcov.ge/en

If you identify symptoms of COVID-19, call 112 or contact directly your family doctor. After that you will be redirected to testing.   The need for PCR test is identified by a family doctor. PCR test is free when is conducted by a reference of a family doctor.  http://web.archive.org/web/20211128174752/https://stopcov.ge/en

In the case of a positive COVID-19 test the person is required to share information about his/her contacts and whereabouts with epidemiologists in order to identify contacts and slow the spread of the virus; notify everyone with whom he/she has been in contact during the 48 hours prior to the onset of the symptoms that he/she has been infected.   http://web.archive.org/web/20211128181407/https://stopcov.gov.ge/en/Martva
Uniform wearing of facemasks has become mandatory both indoors and outdoors.  http://web.archive.org/web/20211128162627/https://stopcov.ge/en/page/restrictions-list

Vaccination is accessible for Georgian citizens over 18. In Georgia vaccination is free of charge and voluntary. Citizens of Georgia aged 60 and above, who will get vaccinated with the first dose against COVID-19 through 31st December 2021, will be paid 200 GEL as a one-off promotional supplement.  http://web.archive.org/web/20211128174752/https://stopcov.ge/en
No changes in recommendations found.  http://web.archive.org/web/20211128162627/https://stopcov.ge/en/page/restrictions-list

If you have not been vaccinated and travel out of Nuuk or Sisimiut, you must be quarantined for five days and tested for COVID-19 when you arrive at your destination in Greenland. You must be tested on the 5th day or later after departure, and if your test is negative, you are considered not to be infected. If you do not allow yourself to be tested on the 5th day, you must stay in the same city for a minimum of 14 consecutive days prior to the trip before you can travel on to another city.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211111213824/https://corona.nun.gl/da/rejser/indenrigsrejser-i-gronland/

If you have not been vaccinated and travel out of Nuuk or Sisimiut, you must be quarantined for five days and tested for COVID-19 when you arrive at your destination in Greenland. You must be tested on the 5th day or later after departure, and if your test is negative, you are considered not to be infected. If you do not allow yourself to be tested on the 5th day, you must stay in the same city for a minimum of 14 days in a row prior to the trip before you can travel on to another city.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211111213824/https://corona.nun.gl/da/rejser/indenrigsrejser-i-gronland/

People aged 12+ who travel from Nuuk or Upernavik to another place in Greenland must, as a rule, be fully vaccinated against COVID-19. A negative PCR test is not enough. You are considered fully vaccinated against COVID-19 when you have completed a vaccination process and can document this.  If you are fully vaccinated, you can travel out of Nuuk or Upernavik without first having to present a negative coronate test.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211124000352/https://corona.nun.gl/da/rejser/indenrigsrejser-i-gronland/

Only fully-vaccinated individuals or residents of Greenland can travel to Greenland. Required negative-COVID-19 test taken in the UK, nordic country, or the EU within 72 hours of travelling.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211111214222/https://corona.nun.gl/da/rejser/indrejse-til-gronland/

To travel into Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated or resident in Greenland or on your way to move to Greenland. As well, you must show proof of a negative COVID PCR test from a Nordic country, the UK, or a country in the EU within the last 72 hours.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211111214222/https://corona.nun.gl/da/rejser/indrejse-til-gronland/

Schools and colleges are adapting to the situation on a daily basis, and in order to provide education to all students in educational institutions, a hybrid model of education has been introduced - some have continued classroom teaching and some have introduced online teaching to prevent the spread of coronavirus. The new condition is also the physical distance that everyone must adhere to, so in educational institutions it is precisely determined what the distance between the tables must be, when the masks must be worn and how long the school lesson or lecture will last. What is school without its students?    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112162611/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-skolovanju/13
No change in policy.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211115185023/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-skolovanju/13
Recommendation exist, same as previously
No policy change

In order to adapt as much as possible to the new conditions, employers are advised to organize, wherever possible, work from home or work in shifts, in order to avoid interference by workers. For the protection of one's own, but also the health of others, it is recommended that all business trips be postponed and that meetings be held online. Jobs related to the health care system also have specially prescribed measures that employees must adhere to so that the system itself is not overloaded. All recommendations for employees and employers in trade, catering facilities, measures for drivers in road freight transport or employees in the state administration, can be found here.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112163018/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-poslu/46
No change in policy.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112163018/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-poslu/46
Recommendation exist, same as previously

Gatherings - measures take effect tomorrow    Today, the Headquarters passed a new Decision which regulates, ie restricts gatherings, which will take effect tomorrow , and the most important changes are:    It is forbidden to hold all public events and gatherings indoors where more than 50 people are present in one place, unless it is a public event or gathering attended only by persons with an EU digital COVID certificate , and the same is the responsibility of the civil headquarters. protection of local self-government units gave consent. (so far it referred to more than 100)  Measures are being tightened to hold all public events and gatherings indoors with more than 50 people, where, with the participation of the EU digital COVID certificate, it will be mandatory to use a medical mask or face mask and maintain the necessary physical distance . (so far this has not been mandatory for gatherings with the EU digital COVID certificate).  The measure of banning all public events and outdoor gatherings attended by more than 100 people in one place is still valid, unless it is a public event or gathering attended only by persons with an EU digital COVID certificate .  All ** public events and gatherings ** must end no later than 24.00 hours, which means that gatherings with EU digital COVID certificates for which the local headquarters has given consent for maintenance cannot last longer than 24.00 hours , nor professional artistic performances and programs, exhibitions in museum spaces and similar cultural events. * The only exceptions are cinema screenings that started before 23.00 and can end after 24.00. Also, wedding ceremonies where all those present have EU digital COVID certificates must end no later than 02.00 (so far they have not been limited in time), and additional time limits will be considered according to the epidemiological situation. *  congresses and conferences will be able to be held only if all those present have an EU digital COVID certificate , and the condition is that it is mandatory to use medical masks or face masks and to maintain physical distance.  Sports competitions will be able to be held in the presence of spectators only if everyone has EU digital COVID certificates (there is no possibility of attending up to 100 spectators with an epidemiological framework developed by the County Institute of Public Health and County Headquarters), and indoors spectators except the EU Digital COVID certification, you must also use medical masks or face masks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112163612/https://www.koronavirus.hr/od-06-11-ogranicenja-za-okupljanja-a-od-15-11-covid-potvrde-u-drzavnim-i-javnim-slu%C5%BEbama-uklju%C4%8Dujuci-i-skole/992

No change in policy. There will be a change in policy regarding Covid certificates in government services, including schools, starting on 05/11/21.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211114221129/https://koronavirus.hr/od-06-11-ogranicenja-za-okupljanja-a-od-15-11-covid-potvrde-u-drzavnim-i-javnim-slu%C5%BEbama-uklju%C4%8Dujuci-i-skole/992

We take increased care of hand hygiene on a daily basis, avoid touching our eyes, nose and mouth with dirty hands, and handling and direct contact should be kept to a minimum. Going out, visiting museums and entertainment in general are temporarily restricted, all in order to maximize the impact on preventing the spread of coronavirus indoors. During all events and trips, it is important to adhere to the prescribed measures and recommendations. Regarding occupational health, it is recommended to introduce work from home or shift work, in order to avoid unwanted situations as much as possible. In order to protect yourself and others, you avoid gatherings, but do not forget to help those who need help the most today, our elderly fellow citizens. It is primarily important for everyone to preserve health, because when a person is healthy - he can do a lot.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210827182507/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-svakodnevnom-zivotu/185
No change in policy.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210827182507/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-svakodnevnom-zivotu/185

Passengers traveling to the Republic of Croatia from one of the EU / EEA Member States  Passengers coming directly from EU member states and / or regions, ie Schengen member states and / or regions and countries associated with the Schengen area, regardless of citizenship, will be allowed to enter the Republic of Croatia if they have a valid EU digital COVID certificate.    If the said persons transited through other countries / regions without delay during the journey to the border crossings of the Republic of Croatia, they should prove at the border crossing that they did not stay in the transit areas.    The EU digital COVID certificate is a certificate issued in accordance with Regulation (EU) 2021/953 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 14 June 2021 on a framework for the issuance, verification and acceptance of interoperable COVID-19 vaccination, testing and recovery certificates. COVID certificate) to facilitate free movement during the COVID-19 pandemic.       Exceptionally, passengers coming directly from the countries and / or regions of the European Union or the countries and / or regions of the Schengen area and the countries associated to the Schengen area, and do not yet have an EU digital COVID certificate, will be allowed to enter the Republic of Croatia with:     negative PCR test or  rapid antigen test - BAT  on SARS-CoV-2, where the BAT test must be from the  Common list of rapid antigen tests mutually recognized by the Member States of the European Union , published by the European Commission. When finding a  BAT  test made abroad, the test manufacturer and / or the commercial name of the test must be visible. Otherwise, the test will not be accepted as credible for entry into the Republic of Croatia. The result of the PCR test must not be older than 72 hours, and the BAT test of 48 hours from the moment of testing until the arrival at the border crossing.   confirmation not older than 365 days of receipt of two doses of vaccine used in EU Member States (Pfizer, Moderna, AstaZeneca, Gamaleya, Sinopharm) or presentation of a certificate not older than 365 days of receipt of one dose of vaccine received in one dose (Janssen / Johnson & Johnson) if 14 days have passed since receiving that one dose;  confirmation of recovery from COVID-19 and receipt of a single dose of vaccine within eight months of the onset of the disease, provided that vaccination must be carried out less than 365 days before arrival at the border crossing;   confirmation of receipt of the first dose of Pfizer, Moderna or Gamaleya, with which it is possible to enter the Republic of Croatia in the period from 22 to 42 days from the receipt of the vaccine, or from 22 to 84 days from the first dose of AstraZeneca;  presentation of a positive PCR or  rapid antigen test,  confirming that the owner has recovered from SARS-CoV-2 virus infection, which test was performed 365 days ago, and older than 11 days from the date of arrival at the border crossing or presentation of a medical certificate about the patient ;  or perform PCR testing or  rapid antigen testing - BAT  on SARS-CoV-2 immediately upon arrival in the Republic of Croatia (at its own expense), with the obligation of self-isolation until the arrival of a negative finding. In case of impossibility of testing, a measure of self-isolation is determined for a period of ten (10) days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112165703/https://www.koronavirus.hr/o-covidu/733

Aid to preserve jobs - short-time work scheme for 2021  The aid is granted for temporary introduction of the short-time work scheme for employees in a manner that employees work full time, but shorter than the usual monthly fund of working hours, up to a maximum of 90% of working hours. At the annual level there the short-time work scheme cannot cover more than 70% of the annual fund of working hours.    The aid is calculated based on the formula whereas HRK 4,000 (approx. EUR 525) is divided by the monthly fund of hours for the month the aid is being requested for,and multiplied by the number of hours covered by the aid. The amount of aid is calculated in accordance with HZZâs Table of the financing amount based on the number and percentage of working hours available on this link. The aid can amount to up to HRK 3,600 (approx. EUR 475) per employee.    The employers have to apply for the aid each month for the following month.     The employer must pay the full monthly salary and calculate and pay the social security contributions for the whole salary (including the part covered by the aid). If the aid is granted, it will be paid for the previous month and the State will refund the contributions to the employer.    The aid may be granted only for employees that have been employed on the last day of the month preceding the month for which the aid is requested, excluding workers on notice period, teleworkers, outsourced workers, workers on annual or another leave. Also, workers covered by the aid may not work overtime nor be replaced by other workers.    The aid will be available for months from 1 January to 31 December 2021.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211109113252/https://cms.law/en/int/expert-guides/cms-expert-guide-to-state-aid-in-the-eu-during-coronavirus-crisis/croatia

Vaccination is voluntary and free and is the fastest way to victory in the fight against COVID-19, and the key is to vaccinate the vast majority of citizens. Vaccination protects you and the people you live with or come in contact with. All vaccines registered in Croatia and the European Union effectively protect against severe forms of disease, hospitalization and death. On this page you can find more information about vaccinations and vaccines used in Croatia.  All citizens residing or residing in Croatia can be vaccinated against COVID-19. Vaccines are not intended for children under 16 or 18 years of age, and the vaccination age depends on the type of vaccine. However, due to the higher risk of developing more severe forms of COVID-19 disease, preference is given to people with chronic diseases and the elderly. These include people with respiratory, cardiovascular, malignant, kidney diseases, diabetes and immunodeficiencies.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211114003829/https://www.koronavirus.hr/o-cijepljenju/329
https://web.archive.org/web/20211114003829/https://www.koronavirus.hr/o-cijepljenju/329

3. CAN I GET VACCINATED AGAINST SARS-COV-2 OUTSIDE MY RESIDENCE?  If you are not able to be vaccinated in your place of residence, or with the chosen family doctor, you can apply for vaccination via the portal cijepise.zdravlje.hr or the competent county public health institute in the place of your current residence.     4. CAN PERSONS WITH EUROPEAN HEALTH INSURANCE BE VACCINATED?  According to the instructions of the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Croatia, vaccination of persons who are insured by the Croatian Health Insurance Institute is currently underway, and therefore it is currently not possible to vaccinate persons who are not in this category.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211114221151/https://koronavirus.hr/o-covidu/892    COVID-19 Vaccine Information:  Has the government of Croatia approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use? Yes  Are vaccines available in Croatia for U.S. citizens to receive? Yes  Which vaccines are available in Croatia? PfizerâBioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson.  According to the Croatian Institute for Public Health, foreigners with temporary or permanent residency in Croatia can register for the COVID-19 vaccine through their local healthcare provider.  If you have an OIB (Croatian Personal Identification Number) and a local health insurance plan, you may visit https://cijepise.zdravlje.hr/ to register to get vaccinated.  If you do not have a local health insurance plan, you may visit the following Croatian Institute of Public Health website for the contact details of the county public health institutes to register by phone.  Visit the FDAâs website to?learn more about FDA-approved vaccines?in the United States.  The United States Government does not plan to provide COVID-19 vaccinations to private U.S. citizens overseas. Please follow host country developments and guidelines for COVID-19 vaccination.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211122084519/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Schools are fully open across the country   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211126143913/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse
There are no restrictions on workplaces opening.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211126144451/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis
Public events can go ahead, and are doing so.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211126144451/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

Events of more than 500 people can only be attended with a security card, proving immunity status. At indoor cultural and other events, gyms, swimming pools, spas, and  catering shops, employees must wear a mask.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211126144451/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis
All public transport remains open  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211126144451/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis
There is currently no governmental recommendations or requirement to stay at home in Hungary  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211126144451/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis
There are no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211126145356/https://hu.usembassy.gov/covid-19/

You can enter Hungary by road, rail and waterway from all the countries neighbouring Hungary (Croatia, Austria, Romania, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia and Ukraine) without any epidemiological restrictions, regardless of your nationality and coronavirus immunity. People coming from other countries require full vaccination status or a negative PCR result from the past 72 hours or face; foreign travellers will also undergo temperature checks upon arrival. Foreign (including UK) nationals entering Hungary for essential business purposes, may enter the country without epidemiological restrictions.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211126145142/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/hungary/entry-requirements
No policy change  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211126144451/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

There is some relief in terms of income tax. People under 25 do not have to pay income tax in January 2022, and in February 2022, parents raising a child will be refunded their income tax paid in 2021 up to the average wage tax level. Additionally, the credit moratorium was extended until June 30, 2022.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211126144451/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis  Source:

There is a dedicated "General information on the epidemiological situation, vaccination, vaccines and measures" on the government website to allow people to access up to date information.  Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20211126144451/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

A PCR test for coronavirus is ordered in all people who are suspected of having a coronavirus. This is ordered by your GP, epidemiologist or hospital and is completely free. You only have to pay for the test if you decide you want to have it tested.   Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20211126144451/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis
There is not a comprehensive contact tracing programme currently in place  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211126144451/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

Mask should be worn in stores, shopping centres, post offices, the customer services,  health care facilities, public transport, the theaters, cinemas, museums and sporting events. At indoor cultural and other events, gyms, swimming pools, spas, and  catering shops, employees must wear a mask . In crÃ¨ches, kindergartens, schools, principals and in higher education institutions, rectors, and in other workplaces, employers can determine the rules for wearing a mask.  Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20211126144451/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

The government has announced "Vaccine Action Week" from the 22nd to the 29th of November to encourage wider uptake of the vaccine. During this week, people can go to hospital vaccinations without prior registration and appointment.   All 101 hospitals in the country, as well as specialist clinics in some counties, are offering this service from seven in the morning to seven in the evening.  Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20211126144451/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis
A broad ban on hospital visitors has been announced, coming into effect from November 20th.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211126144451/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

19 Nov 2021, Government approves additional measures to reduce levels of social contact and interrupt the spread of COVID-19.   There will be no change in current arrangements for student attendance and on-site activities in school, further and higher education institutions in line with COVID response plans for those sectors.    https://www.gov.ie/en/press-release/b4bec-statement-on-covid-19-public-health-measures-16-november-2021/
COVID-19 certification needs to be presented to enter places.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211120151549/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/covid19/living_with_covid19_plan.html

From Friday 19 November 2021, everyone should return to working from home unless absolutely necessary to attend in person. This advice remains in place until further notice.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211118180328/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/employment/employment_rights_and_conditions/health_and_safety/working_at_home.html

19 Nov 2021, Government approves additional measures to reduce levels of social contact and interrupt the spread of COVID-19.   - COVID-19 passes needed (based on vaccination or recovery) for cinemas and theatres  - Closing times for all on-licensed premises, including hotel bars and hotel residentsâ bars, will move to midnight with all customers vacated from the premises by that time, regardless of the event taking place place (for example: weddings, dinner dances and other similar style functions all finish at midnight)    https://www.gov.ie/en/press-release/b4bec-statement-on-covid-19-public-health-measures-16-november-2021/

29th Nov 2021,  In response to cases of the new variant SARS-CoV-2 Variant B.1.1.529 (Omicron), our current advice is to avoid all non-essential travel to the following designated States - Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Zimbabwe.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211125223653/https://www.dfa.ie/travel/travel-advice/coronavirus/general-covid-19-travel-advisory/

From Friday, December 3, 2021, all arrivals aged 12 and over who are fully vaccinated or recovered from COVID-19 must provide either a negative or not detected antigen test (taken within 48 hours before arrival) or a negative or not detected RT-PCR test (taken within 72 hours before arrival.    http://web.archive.org/web/20211204085256/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/ireland-imposes-compulsory-covid-19-test-requirement-for-all-arrivals-from-december-3/

From Sunday 5 December 2021, all arrivals aged 12 and over who are fully vaccinated or recovered from COVID-19 must provide either of the following:    A negative or not detected antigen test (taken within 48 hours before arrival)  A negative or not detected RT-PCR test (taken within 72 hours before arrival)  The test result must be certified and not self-administered.    If you are not fully vaccinated or recovered, you must show a negative or not detected RT-PCR test taken within 72 hours before your arrival.     http://web.archive.org/web/20211203185527/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/covid19/living_with_covid19_plan.html

19 Nov 2021, The government continues to offer a range of economic supports to assist businesses and individuals impacted by the pandemic as set out in the Economic Recovery Plan, which are amongst the most extensive direct supports offered within the EU. They include the Employment Wage Subsidy Scheme (with expenditure to date of over â¬5.4bn), tax warehousing, a targeted commercial rates waiver, along with low-cost loan schemes to businesses, such as the COVID-19 Credit Guarantee Scheme, mentoring programmes, and direct grant programmes. A range of sectoral supports also remain in place and, through the Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, the Gaeltacht, Sports and the Media, the government remains in ongoing contact with the hospitality and entertainment sectors on the challenges they face due to COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211120170638/https://www.gov.ie/en/press-release/b4bec-statement-on-covid-19-public-health-measures-16-november-2021/

19 Nov 2021, Antigen testing for close contacts  The HSE advise that you should do 3 antigen tests in total. You can do them at any time of the day.    You should do your 3 antigen tests in this order:    - first test on the day you get your tests  - second test 2 days after your first test  - third test 2 days after your second test    https://web.archive.org/web/20211120170638/https://www.gov.ie/en/press-release/b4bec-statement-on-covid-19-public-health-measures-16-november-2021/

19 Nov 2021, Booster vaccinations are currently being administered to those aged over 60 in the community and residents in long-term care facilities, the immunocompromised, and healthcare workers. The Health Service Executive (HSE) is already planning to expand capacity further through both the pharmacy sector and vaccination centres over the coming weeks, and will now plan a further ramp-up of the delivery programme in the coming days in line with the National Immunisation Advisory Committee (NIAC) advice received last night to extend the programme to those aged 16-59 with underlying conditions and to those aged 50 to 59.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211120170638/https://www.gov.ie/en/press-release/b4bec-statement-on-covid-19-public-health-measures-16-november-2021/

Secondary schools and universities using distance learning and limited running of nursery schools and primary schools.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211113215622/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/iceland-s-response    Restrictions to take place at midnight, 13 November - School activities:  1. The general 50 person restriction applies to school activities, except for children born in 2016 and after. Children born in 2006 and after will be exempt from using face masks.  2. Pre-school staff members are not required to wear face masks when interacting with pre-school children.  3. Elementary school teachers are permitted to remove their face masks after the children have sat down in their classrooms.  4. Upper secondary school students and teachers are permitted to remove their face masks after they have sat down in their classrooms.  5. Mixing between school groups is permitted at all school levels.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211113221015/https://www.government.is/news/article/2021/11/12/COVID-19-Stricter-measures-a-50-person-restriction-on-the-number-of-people-at-gatherings-and-a-substantial-vaccination-push/

The Regulation on restrictions on gatherings due the pandemic will apply to 8 December 2021.  Restrictions to the number of people at gatherings:  The maximum number of people allowed in the same location is 50 persons, with certain restrictions, both in public and private locations, outdoors and indoors. Restrictions on the number of people and the social distancing rule do not apply to children born 2016 or later.    Up to 500 people may attend an event if additional conditions are met:  -All attendees must present a negative rapid antigen test taken no longer than 48 hours in advance, from a certified test center. Note that self-tests are not accepted.  -1 meter distancing rule except when seated.  -All guests must be registered stating their name, ID No. and telephone number. This information must be kept on file for two weeks. If guests are in numbered seats they must be registered.  -Face masks must be worn indoors wherever the 1 metre social distancing rule cannot be observed. This rule does not apply at school dances. Children born 2006 and later are exempt from wearing a mask.  -Refreshments may not be sold during intervals.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211113223052/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/effective-restrictions

The following rules are in force from 5. November 2021 and will apply up to and including 9. November 2021.    Restrictions on gatherings:  The maximum number of people allowed in the same location is 2000 persons, with certain restrictions, both in public and private locations, outdoors and indoors. Unlimited number of people may attend an event if all guests bring a negative result from a rapid antigen test. Restrictions on the number of people do not apply to children born 2006 or later.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211111082710/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/effective-restrictions

Up to 500 people may attend an event if additional conditions are met:  -All attendees must present a negative rapid antigen test taken no longer than 48 hours in advance, from a certified test center. Face masks must be used where it is not possible to ensure 1 metre of social distancing, such as in healthcare services, shops, museums, domestic flights and ferries, public transport, taxis and coaches, in practical driving lessons and flight training, hairdressers, beauty salons, massage parlours, tattoo parlours, dog grooming salons, tanning salons and other similar activities.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211113223052/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/effective-restrictions

Rules at the border are in force from October 1, 2021.    -All travellers must pre-register before arriving in Iceland and confirm their departure day, if available.  -Rules for travellers without a network in Iceland: Present a negative PCR test certificate against COVID-19. Rapid antigen tests are not valid. The test must have been taken within 72 hours before departure on the first leg of the journey. A fine for not presenting a negative PCR-test is at the border is 100.000 ISK.  -Travelers must undergo testing upon arrival to Iceland.  -Quarantine and second testing: Everybody must quarantine for five days and go for another test at the end of quarantine. Please note that a new day begins at midnight. People may quarantine at home provided that their accommodation meets certain conditions. Here is a list of accommodations that accommodate guests in quarantine.  -Go directly to the quarantine location from the border entry point by airport bus, taxi, rental car or private car. Travellers are advised to stay overnight at a guesthouse near the border entry point if they are tired or the weather is bad.  -Testing and quarantine of children: Children under the age of 18 are permitted to travel to Iceland with their parents, given the parents are exempt from travel restrictions to Iceland. However, children born in or before 2004 need to undergo testing at the border, quarantine for 5 days and then be tested a second time, unless they have a certificate of full vaccination. Children born in 2005 or later are exempt from the rules at the border.  -The second testing is done at health centres around Iceland. A bar code is sent to a mobile phone the night before testing. Please note the different opening hours for testing.  -A positive result will always result in isolation, and in such cases, the instructions on home isolation must be followed. If an individual is diagnosed with a variant of the virus that is more contagious and/or causes a more serious illness, the person in question is unconditionally required to stay in a quarantine hotel. Isolation in the quarantine hotel is free of charge, and referral is in the hands of the infection tracing team and the COVID Outpatient Department at LandspÃ­tali.  -It is recommended that travellers download the Rakning C-19 app. It is used, amongst other things, to communicate negative testing results and helps to trace infections if necessary.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211122050142/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/risk-areas

no changes in policy, green passes are still required for university students.    Starting September 1st green passes are required for School Personnel only. All students are exempted from this requirement for the time being until and including high school. University students though need to have green passes in order to access the facilities of their university. Universities hence are virtually closed for students without a green pass.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211029162316/https://www.tgcom24.mediaset.it/skuola/universita-tra-green-pass-e-click-day-per-i-postiin-aula-il-ritorno-in-presenza-e-una-corsa-a-ostacoli_40078167-202102k.shtml
